As someone who was dipping my toes into something completely new, web development, I did not know where to start, what to do in order to put myself in a position to be the most successful. Like every other newbies I've met, I started doing the typical Google search "how to build websites?". My results consisted of a lot of drag and drop site generators, information about bootcamps, etc. None of which helped! 
A good friend of mine then suggested this amazing website called

and my luck started to turn. I started purchasing courses for the price of a coffee cup. This new found tool opened a world of learning for me. It allowed me to learn, practice and build little quick landing pages. Now for the down side of all of this, while purchasing courses on udemy would help me practice with all of the training wheels on, it slowly dragged me into what's known as "tutorial hell", which is the inability to put what you've been learning into practice. My rude awakening came when I attempted to rebuild one of the sites I built so easily during my udemy course. I did not know up from down, left from right. I found myself going back to the video over and over, even to start it. Self doubt started to creep in, the feeling of not being able to do the basics made me feel as if maybe this web development thing just might not be for me after all. 
In come the discovery that changed my learning path as a developer, the #100DaysOfCode challenge. What is that you may ask? Well, it's simple really, code for at least 1hr a day for 100 days. Sounds easy enough I assumed! I quickly learned how difficult it was to even get started with this challenge. Let me tell you exactly how I managed to overcome all the hurdles and managed to accomplish this challenge as well as all the good and bad habits it brought my way!
